content: The "Canine Detection Team Improvement Act of 2007" amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to enhance coordination and training for canine detection teams. The "Canine Detection Team Improvement Act of 2007" amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to enhance coordination and training for canine detection teams. It includes provisions for coordinating canine training programs, research on new training methods, and maximizing the use of existing training facilities and resources. The Secretary is required to prioritize increasing the use of domestically bred canines for counter-terrorism missions, consult with various organizations to encourage domestic breeding, and consolidate canine procurement across the Federal Government. The Secretary is consolidating canine procurement across the Federal Government to reduce purchasing costs. The Secretary is establishing a grant program for domestic breeders of canines to support targeted breeding programs for detection purposes in the US. $3,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. Additionally, a Homeland Security Canine Detection Accreditation Board will be created. The Secretary will establish a Homeland Security Canine Detection Accreditation Board within 180 days of issuing national voluntary consensus standards. The Board will consist of experts in canine training and explosives detection to certify compliance with the standards. The Accreditation Board will establish a voluntary process to certify canine detection teams, ensuring they meet national standards and do not pose risks to public safety. They will maintain a public list of accredited entities. Compliance with standards must begin within 180 days of their establishment. The Secretary will require grant funds to not be used for acquiring a canine detection team unless the team is certified under the established process or special circumstances justify acquiring uncertified canines. The definitions in this subtitle include terms like "canine detection team," "certifying entity," and "SWGDOG." The table of sections is amended to include a new title XIX for the Domestic Nuclear Detection Office. Title XIX establishes the Domestic Nuclear Detection Office with various authorities and relationships outlined. Subtitle A of Title XIX focuses on Canine Detection Teams, including coordination of training, procurement of canines, a breeding grant program, accreditation board, and definitions. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to report on plans to consolidate canine training programs within 120 days of the Act's enactment.
